name: What happens when you enter a website in a browser

body.text:
if domain is not present in the hosts file it will make a DNS request via a specified nameserver.

But before sending a DNS packet to a nameserver. It should first find which device to send it. For this it needs to perform ARP lookup.

items.name: Hosts file
items.description:
As your machine gets started, it will need to know the mapping of some hostnames to IP addresses before DNS can be referenced. On Linux this mapping is kept in the /etc/hosts file. In the absence of a name server, any network program on your system consults this file to determine the IP address that corresponds to a host name.

Here is an example of how it looks like:

127.0.0.1       localhost   deep.openna.com
208.164.186.1   deep.openna.com  deep
208.164.186.2   mail.openna.com  mail
208.164.186.3   web.openna.com  web

body.text: If domain is not present in cache, it then calls gethostbyname
it first checks if domain is present in the hosts file

TCP packets have to travel through numerous hops to get from a laptop all the way to a server. A server can be physically located in another country or another continent. To get to the server TCP packets have to navigate through various so-called "Autonomous Systems" with a help of Border Gateway Protocol. Click BGP to get more information
What happens when you open a website in your browser?
This is an interactive diagram that demonstrates you what happens behind the scenes when you open a website. All elements in this diagram are clickable
